text:
You insisted we connect over phone so as not to use up OFW minutes
I told you repeatedly I wanted to get off the phone and NO to your request. Probably 30 times I said no. I then got upset after I clearly stated my
boundaries, and communicated I had boundaries. You then said, see, your reaction!
For Max, we clearly discussed plan for am. I said I did not need any additional help.
In regards to your communication with him, it has been communicated to you for months now, reunification therapy is needed.
That has not happened.
Message 2173 of 4024
Drop in. I am not dropping in on you. If you have devices that allow me to drop in, then change permission settings. I don’t have access and control
to whatever settings you say I have. If you are insisting I do that, let’s have a third party review my phone records to determine if I am in fact doing
that. If I am as you allege, then I will pay for that review. If I am not, then you pay for it.
Sent:03/16/2024 at 07:52 AM
From:Christine Moyer
To:Robert Moyer (First Viewed: 03/16/2024 at 09:56 AM)
Subject:Re: Running List for 3/15
Message 2174 of 4024
Drop in. I am not dropping in on you.
<<Thank you for the reassurance but I don't feel great tbh. I see the attempts, screen capture them, share that instant, and ask about them. Just as I do
the constant daily Xfinity alerts that your ISP sends me. As explained before, the devices you used to drop in on me were in active use, going back to
our Beach days as a family. They were the two cam/audio Alexa devices that we used when we could not find our phones. The Kirkland home
initiated these calls from either the Kitchen or your office. Everyone in our family knows this and has used it. This will never be up for debate and the
kids can both explain it.
If you have devices that allow me to drop in, then change permission settings.
<<I only have these devices because you shipped them to me for my use inside my home instead of in the Kirkland home. I plugged them in and was
simply ignorant you sent me audio/video equipment that would allow you that capability. It honestly felt innocent at the time. I can't change your
permission settings any more than I can change permissions on Xfinity. They are yours. You control them. If it confuses you to understand why
Amazon would not let anybody take over your audio/video drop-in devices just because they physically have them and then allow this, think about
what that means in nefarious situations.>>
I don’t have access and control to whatever settings you say I have.
<<Thank you for the reassurance. I will look again to verify if that is true. I sent you screen captures that say otherwise as recently as last weekend. But
perhaps you will relinquished that capability this week. That would make me feel better. Note I believe I have unplugged everything you sent me and
only see alerts on my phone. I hope that effectively stops the drop-ins from connecting but not the initiation of the attempt. You own those.  You
recall how livid you were when our proposed RO was a mutual ask to stop this, but insisted if we asked, you would move forward with a DV charges
against me so we could not>>
If you are insisting I do that, let’s have a third party review my phone records to determine if I am in fact doing that.
Sent:03/16/2024 at 12:30 PM
From:Robert Moyer
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 03/16/2024 at 12:51 PM)
Subject:Re: Running List for 3/15
